pullRequest.body:
An implementation of the Schwartz-Zippel lemma

Sometimes also called the DeMillo–Lipton–Schwartz–Zippel lemma.

---

This PR seems to be passing and have no dependencies. Is it close to ready for merging?

In my opinion, yes. But someone needs to review it (and then a maintainer needs to approve it). You should feel free to review! See https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/pr-review.html for instructions.

By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (🤖). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

One can define evaluation of polynomials over noncommutative rings, but it is not a ring morphism, and the statement will be wrong. For example, the equation $$T^2+1=0$$ on Hamilton quaternions has infinitely many solutions, and the finite set $$S=\{i,j,k\}$$ is a counterexample.
Yes, I think this should be done here. The same approach should work.

It means bounding above the set of solutions in a product type. A particular case would imply that if $$f$$ is a polynomial in $$T_1,\dots,T_n$$, $$A_1,\dots,A_n$$ are finite sets of cardinalities $$|A_i|>\deg_{T_i}(f)$$ for all $$i$$, then $$f$$ doesn't vanish identically on $$A_1\times\dots\times A_n$$. This is proved in a PR of mine, #16177, as one step of Alon's combinatorial Nullstellensatz.

Are you sure it's a "particular case"? When applying Schwartz-Zippel, I find myself having to prove that $\sum_i \frac{\deg_{T_i}(f)}{|A_i|} < 1$, which doesn't seem true given the mere $\deg_{T_i}(f) < |A_i|$ assumption.

Here is my code, if you want to complete it (with all the `open` from this PR)
```
/-- A corollary of the **Schwartz-Zippel** lemma. -/
lemma exists_mem_piFinset_eval_ne_zero_of_degreeOf_lt_card {n} {p : MvPolynomial (Fin n) R}
    (hp : p ≠ 0) {S : Fin n → Finset R} (hS : ∀ i, (S i).Nonempty) (hpS : p.degreeOf < (#S ·)) :
    ∃ f ∈ S ^^ n, eval f p ≠ 0 := by
  by_contra! h
  refine lt_irrefl (1 : ℚ≥0) ?_
  calc
    (1 : ℚ≥0) = #{f ∈ S ^^ n | eval f p = 0} / ∏ i, (#S i : ℚ≥0) := by
      rw [filter_eq_self.2 h, card_piFinset, Nat.cast_prod, div_self]
      exact prod_ne_zero_iff.2 fun i _ ↦ mod_cast (hS _).card_ne_zero
    _ ≤ ∑ i, (p.degreeOf i / #S i : ℚ≥0) := schwartz_zippel hp _
    _ < 1 := sorry -- Are you sure this is true?
```
No I'm not sure at all. It was rather a guess based on my understanding of what something such as Schwartz-Zippel says (or should say) than an affirmation.

The following paper indicates results that mathlib could host.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2305.10900
Ahahah. This is the paper that Bhavik and I were looking at to try beating your combinatorial nullstellensatz PR 🙈
There's nothing to beat. Let's be adults and do it.
All of this is basic and easy math. The only problem is that it is often written like sh*t. (This paper is nicer, and the one by Pete Clark is cleaner too.)

> There's nothing to beat. Let's be adults and do it.

To be clear, we were not working on the generalisation just to spite you, but rather because we started working on it long before you opened your PR, and we thought it would be a good way to justify keeping working on it

> The only problem is that it is often written like sh*t.

Yes, agree 😓

Yes, I'm not sure where "beat" comes from here - I needed a generalisation of the combinatorial nullstellensatz (one of the ones in that paper) for an application, and started working on it on my own just before your PR. But yours develops a useful amount of theory, and I see no need to block it based off an incomplete generalisation which uses different machinery. Certainly my only motivation to keep working on it is that the generalisation is needed for an application I have in mind.

This discussion makes me wonder what kind of collaborative project mathlib is. In the not exactly similar context of scientific publication, what you hint at (envisioning blocking something because a more general thing is in view) is considered as plainly unacceptable. The normal thing to do would be to mention the expected generalization and to ask whether it can be reached along this line.

I completely agree that blocking your work here would be plainly unacceptable. I simply mean that Lason's version was incomplete by the time you finished Alon's version, and I needed to prioritise other things instead of continuing to work on that.

If I understand correctly, there are three different ongoing works on this kind of ideas:
* the present PR by Bolton on Schwartz-Zippel
* my PR on the combinatorial Nullstellensatz
* subsequent work, eventually by Bhavik and Yaël, on a joint generalization.
May I suggest that then, things are done a bit differently? 
Is it worth the time and effort to commit neat PRs that will soon be superseded or should we join forces towards the envisioned general case? (Of course, that depends upon what “soon” means. And I'm wary of the potential dark holes created by good-will assertions such as “I have this and that good idea in mind that would…”, I've seen too much of them in my other math life.)

I don't quite agree with the third ongoing work - the truth is that I have a 300 line file which exists solely on my laptop, most of which is developing theory unrelated to the Nullstellensatz, but contains a statement of Lason's version at the end. This one gives a slight generalisation of the main result of your PR, and is unrelated to the present PR: there is no known statement of a Nullstellensatz that implies both Alon's Nullstellensatz and the Schwartz-Zippel lemma. This file also hasn't been touched in the last month.

More importantly however, the theory that I began to develop is completely independent of the theory developed in your PR: everything except the last 80 lines in your Nullstellensatz.lean file would not be superseded (ie that's 1.5k lines that I don't plan to alter), and indeed the work there consists of things which ought to be in mathlib.

I'm very happy to join forces here, but where things stand currently I have comparatively little to contribute, so it would ultimately be me attempting to claim credit where it's undeserved.

I agree with your understanding. I should however point out that
1. There is not *one* general case, but *two*. Schwartz-Zippel here is generalised by a different statement to the one generalising the combinatorial nullstellensatz.
2. In light of point 1, I duplicated little to no effort with your combinatorial nullstellensatz PR. Bhavik duplicated a bit before you opened the PR, but he stopped.
3. Most of your work would not be lost if we want to work on the generalisation. Everything about Gröbner bases and monomial division would still be useful. Only the very last part where you deduce the combinatorial nullstellensatz itself would change.
4. Point 1 might actually be a bit of a lie because Bhavik and I have heard that Sammy Luo managed to generalise. I don't know much more than that, though.

Luo's recent work is here: https://arxiv.org/abs/2311.08873. It doesn't seem to mention Schwartz-Zippel at all, instead generalising two other polynomial methods along with CN. I think it's a distraction to this discussion, although the work is interesting.

> Bhavik duplicated a bit before you opened the PR, but he stopped.

I don't believe I duplicated anything - there aren't even any identical statements in my file, let alone proofs!

> It means bounding above the set of solutions in a product type. 

If I'm not mistaken, the statement would be, for a product $$A=\prod_{i\in I}A_i$$ of nonempty finite sets of a domain $$R$$ and a polynomial $$f \in R[(T_i)]$$, then the number $$\delta_A(f)$$ of zeroes of $$f$$ in $$A$$ satisfies $$\delta_A(f) / |A| \leq \sup_d (\sum d_i/|A_i|)$$, the supremum being taken on the support of $$f$$. (IFor $$f\neq 0$$, one can even take $$d$$ to be the largest monomial for the lexicographic degree.)
Antoine, I've already proved this in this PR 😉 (except for the "largest in lexicographic degree" part)
Great!
The lexicographic refinement has to be left for future work, maybe you can just add a note in the file?
Is this an equality of `finset` (as in the original version) — I mean, is there a new notation for `filter` — or is this an equality of sets ?
Yes, this is a new notation for `filter`. See #11582
I'm sorry, what do you mean with this?
If I remove the `set_option` below, I must rename `hp` and `hm` to `_hp` and `_hm` in the statement

I was brought up in a world where polynomials were called `f` and points were called `p`. So this version is quite confusing to me.
Could you please call the elements of `F` something like `x`?

```suggestion
              simp (config := {contextual := true}) [subset_iff, eval_eq_eval_mv_eval', pₓ, hpₓ₀]
```
I don't really mind where the spaces are, but let's be consistent on both sides!
I knew something was itching me with this simp call but I couldn't see what!
This one looks incredibly non-terminal.
Isn't it already done?
No, I have currently proved `_ ≤ ∑ i, (p.support.sup fun s ↦ s i) / #S i`, not `_ ≤ p.support.sup fun s ↦ ∑ i, s i / #S i` (which would be stronger)
Update: It's done.

Could you also add `C_ne_zero`, to match [Polynomial.C_eq_zero](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Polynomial/Basic.html#Polynomial.C_eq_zero) and [Polynomial.C_ne_zero](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Polynomial/Basic.html#Polynomial.C_ne_zero)?

```suggestion
-- We want to be able to refer to `hp`.
```
I don't see an `hm` anywhere.

In any case, I'm not sure doing this is better than changing the statement to use `_ : p ≠ 0` instead of `hp : p ≠ 0`.

I am allowed to name `hp` if it comes before the colon, so I should be allowed to name it if it comes after the colon. 

-- Yaël

If `hp` comes before the colon, it is an argument to the theorem and is named so that you can refer to it during the proof. In this case, the argument gets named on line 56, and the variable name on line 54 is indeed unused, as the linter says. The name given here additionally doesn't seem helpful - I agree with @Command-Master's point. In particular, because of the use of the equation compiler here, coming before or after the colon is not a fair comparison.

You could alternatively write `∀ {n} {p : MvPolynomial (Fin n) R} (S : Fin n → Finset R), p ≠ 0 →` and avoid the underscore altogether.

Can you amend the comment on line 46 to give a justification for why disabling the linter here is necessary?
Yes but I am takin the pov of the api here. A user should be able to provide `hp` as a named argumznt regardless of whether i have used pattern-maching or `induction` to prove my lemma
In that case, please amend the comment on line 46 with this.

Can the docstring mention that here `S` may be different for different variables? That's not the usual statement of the Schwartz–Zippel lemma, so I think it should be mentioned.
Additionally, the bound here isn't the degree of the multivariate polynomial, but the sum of the degree of each variable, which should be mentioned in the docstring
I find using `_ ≤ ∑ i, (p.degreeOf (.succ i) / #(S (.succ i)) : ℚ≥0) + p.degreeOf 0 / #(S 0) := ?_` here and moving the argument after the `calc` nicer aesthetically

```suggestion
            _ ≤ ∑ _xₜ ∈ tail S ^^ n, p.degreeOf 0 := by gcongr; apply filter_subset
```
I am allergic to `apply`, sorry 😁 Here, the better thing would be to remove the explicit arguments to `filter_subset`. They are almost always set to `_`

```suggestion
              simp [Function.comp_def, filter_image, filter_filter]
```

```suggestion
```
Why do you need this rfl? Missing lemma?
Yes, we're missing `coe_consEquiv`, which should come from `simps` but `simps` is currently misconfigured and I am planning to fix it in another PR

```suggestion
    #{x ∈ S ^^ n | eval x p = 0} / ∏ i, (#(S i) : ℚ≥0) ≤ ∑ i, (p.degreeOf i / #(S i) : ℚ≥0) := by
```

pullRequest.title: feat(Algebra/MvPolynomial): Schwartz-Zippel lemma
